full_title_en: Prague C & M Classification for Barrett's Esophagus
medium_description_en: Stratifies severity of Barrett’s esophagus according to endoscopic findings.

seo.meta_description_en: The Prague C & M Classification for Barrett's esophagus stratifies severity of Barrett’s esophagus according to endoscopic findings.
seo.keywords_en: Barrett, barett, barret, prague, prag, prage, esophagus, oesophagus, esophageal ca, esophagus ca, Prague, prague c & m, barretts, barrett, barrett esophagus, Barrett's esophagus, esophageal adenocarcinoma, esophageal cancer, esophagus cancer, oesophageal cancer, BE segment, endoscopy

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: A common mistake is to use the M value to state the length of the tongue above the circumferential segment. M should measure the longest Barrett’s segment, including the longest tongue, and must be at least as long as C.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Regarded as the standard for measuring the length of Barrett’s esophagus.
  • Clinical management of BE patients would benefit greatly from a standardized, straightforward criteria for the endoscopic grading of BE with standard endoscopic equipment.

next_steps.advice_en:
• BE is diagnosed when there is >1 cm of salmon colored mucosa with biopsies revealing intestinal metaplasia.
  • If BE is suspected on endoscopy, at least eight8 biopsies should be obtained to increase diagnostic yield.
  • If nodularity or ulceration is noted, endoscopic mucosal resection should be performed for further classification of underlying pathology.
next_steps.management_en:
• Management of BE depends on pathology findings:
    • Nondysplastic BE: Repeat EGD in 3-5 years.
    • Indefinite for dysplasia: Optimize PPI therapy, repeat EGD with biopsies.
    • Low or High Grade Dysplasia: Endoscopic Eradiation Therapy (radiofrequency ablation).
    • Esophageal Cancer: Endoscopic Eradication Therapy and/or referral to oncology depending on staging.
  • After endoscopic complete eradication of intestinal metaplasia, surveillance EGDs are as follows:
    • Intramucosal Carcinoma or High Grade Dysplasia: EGD every 3 months for 1st year, every 6 months for 2nd year, and annually thereafter.
    • Low Grade Dysplasia: EGD every 6 months for 1st year, and annually thereafter.
  • Regardless of pathology, all patients with BE should be placed on proton pump inhibitors until symptom relief is attained.

about.formula_en:
Circumferential extent of BE above the GE Junction (C value)

  • Measure the distance from the GE junction to the highest location where metaplasia is present, around the entire circumference of the esophagus.

Maximal extent of BE above the GE Junction (M value)

  • Measure the distance from the GE junction to the highest location of metaplasia.
about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

The higher the Prague C&M numbers, the more severe the Barrett's esophagus and the higher the risk of developing cancer.
about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
• Sharma et al (2006) first created the Prague Criteria as a way to provide an authoritative, consensus based, uniform method of accurately recognizing and grading BE. It was both internally (5 members of the working group) and externally (22 nonmembers) validated, with longer tongues of BE and the C value having excellent agreeability between observers.
  • After being used widely, Alvarez et al (2013) studied 187 patients to assess agreeability between Barret’s experts and community endoscopists. There was 89% agreement of C value and 91% agreement of the M value within 2 cm of measurements, with relative agreement of 91% for Barrett's esophagus.
  • Vahabzadeh (2012) also validated the Prague Criteria among 18 gastroenterology trainees, showing high agreement of C and M values regardless of level of training.

Gastrointest Endosc. 2012 Feb;75(2):236-41. doi: 10.1016/j.gie.2011.09.017.

expert_name.description: Joseph Mizrahi, MD, is an internal medicine resident at Stony Brook University Hospital in New York. Born and raised in Brooklyn, New York, Dr. Mizrahi received his medical degree from the Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University, and he is also currently a student at the School of Public Health at Stony Brook University. Dr. Mizrahi's areas of interest include gastroenterology and colorectal cancer prevention and screening.
expert_name.name: Joseph Mizrahi, MD

creator_info.about_en: Prateek Sharma, MD, is an associate professor of medicine in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology, and is affiliated with the University of Kansas Medical Center and Kansas City VA Medical Center. He is a fellow of the American College of Gastroenterology and the American College of Physicians, has served as the Chair of the American College of Gastroenterology Public Relations Committee and American Gastroenterology Association ABIM Subcommittee, and is a member of the American Society Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Research Committee. Dr. Sharma's research interests include upper gastrointestinal diseases, such as Barrett's esophagus, esophageal cancer, and gastroesophageal reflux disease, and he has received the American College of Gastroenterology Governors Award for Excellence in Clinical Research. He has published more than 80 original articles and book chapters in this field, and co-edited the book Barrett's Esophagus & Esophageal Adenocarcinoma.
